description: Polynomial extrapolation fits a polynomial function to expectation values measured at multiple noise levels, then evaluates the polynomial at zero noise. Higher-degree polynomials can capture more complex noise dependencies but require more data points and risk overfitting.

The method is motivated by Taylor expansion: if ⟨O⟩(λ) is analytic in λ, it can be approximated by a polynomial near λ = 0. The degree of the polynomial determines the order of the error term in the extrapolation.
In practice, quadratic (degree-2) or cubic (degree-3) polynomials are most common. Higher degrees rarely improve results due to increased variance and numerical instability.
how_it_works: Measure expectation values ⟨O⟩ᵢ at n+1 distinct noise levels λ₀, λ₁, ..., λₙ for a degree-n polynomial.
Fit the polynomial ⟨O⟩(λ) = a₀ + a₁λ + a₂λ² + ... + aₙλⁿ using least squares or Lagrange interpolation.
For exact interpolation with n+1 points and degree n, the fit passes through all data points.
advantages: Systematic: degree-n polynomial has O(λⁿ⁺¹) bias
Flexible: can capture various noise dependencies
Easy to implement with standard numerical libraries
disadvantages: Requires n+1 data points for degree-n polynomial
Risk of overfitting with high-degree polynomials
Numerically unstable for high degrees or closely-spaced λ values
May give unphysical results (e.g., extrapolating outside [-1, 1] for expectation values)
